ygData.subject: Re: GECCO Recap
ygData.msgSnippet: There s definitely a variety of stuff going on at GECCO and most of it doesn t have to do with ANN s directly, but there were a few papers on evolving an ANN

There's definitely a variety of stuff going on at GECCO and most of 
it doesn't have to do with ANN's directly, but there were a few 
papers on evolving an ANN to do something.  But they were mostly 
very uninteresting experiments, such as classification.  I think the 
most interesting neuroevolution outside of NEAT is coming from 
Floreano and his group, who do evolutionary robotics using 
neuroevolution.  Our own group from UT also had several 
presentations, including one by Faustino Gomez on transferring 
neuroevolved controllers to the real world.

It's true that half of GECCO is Genetic Programming.  That's 
becausee GECCO is a combination of the old GA and GP conferences, 
which used to be separate.  GP is kind of strange in that it's just 
one method yet it is treated like a whole area.  This distinction 
between GA and GP may be fading though over the long term as 
indirect encoding becomes more prominent.

In fact, attention to indirect encoding was the big thing I noticed 
changing at this conference.  For the first time since I started 
attending 4 years ago, it got a lot of attention and communities are 
starting to form.  People seem to have suddenly taken notice that 
it's going to be a big deal.

Coevolution is also getting a lot of attention, but mostly at a more 
theoretical level than practical.  Still, there was interesting work 
on cooperative and competitive coevolution, which are definitely 
both relevant to neuroevolution, and most of the leaders in this 
area go to GECCO.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> On Tue, 06 Jul 2004 21:04:55 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> 
wrote:
> > Did you discover any new NEAT or NEAT like research going on or 
any
> > interesting commercial connections?
> 
> Not really.
> 
> I attended a "Genetic Algorithms in Industry" tutorial, which 
actually
> turned out to be two guys from Dow Chemical, so it was 
really "Genetic
> Algorithms in the Chemical Industry".  They spoke in very vague 
terms
> for the first half hour, and when they finally put some data up on 
the
> slides, when someone asked what they were representing, they 
mumbled
> something about how they couldn't say what the graphs actually 
showed
> because it was proprietary.
> 
> GECCO is apparently a fusion of different conferences, and it 
seemed
> to me that many more of the papers and workshops/tutorials were 
geared
> more toward Genetic Programming than any other use of GAs.
> 
> There was an interesting presentation in my LBP session by a guy 
from
> a company that had successfully used GP techniques to identify
> unexploded ordnance in military artillery ranges that were to be
> converted to civilian use.  I spoke to another guy from somewhere
> called Aerospace Corp who said he was skeptical of ANNs and mostly
> looking for GP-based approaches to analyzing aerial and satellite
> photography.  It seems to me that ANN-based approaches to these 
sorts
> of fuzzy recognition problems would be more promising than GP
> approaches...so if anything I got a lot of ideas about potential
> commercial connections, if anything.
> 
> Maybe Ken or Joseph had different experiences, though.
> 
> Derek
